properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow with local blowing snow today and Wednesday. Snow at times heavy is expected today and tonight into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts in the 10 to 20 cm range are expected by Wednesday. In addition, visibilities will be reduced in snow and blowing snow as northwesterly winds gust up to 50 km/h. The snow is associated with a low pressure system near James Bay. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T02:31:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T10:32:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0919979834.2019
Area: Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Early season snow squalls expected late Wednesday evening. Total snowfall: Locally 10 cm or more over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h. Locations: west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: late Wednesday evening through early Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Snowfall accumulations along the coast are not expected to be significant as temperatures should remain near the freezing mark. However, for areas inland and over higher terrain, air temperatures will be cooler so snowfall accumulations could reach or exceed 10 cm and visibilities may be reduced in blowing snow. Conditions will improve Thursday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-06T00:59:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T09:00:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3919865564.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert For Portions Of The Red River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Red River from Letellier through the City of Winnipeg (except for Ste. Agathe and St. Jean Baptiste) due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-05T15:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-04T14:09:52-06:00, 0305101A-A6AB-E1CA-B394-A914CF0CCCA2
Area: The Red River from Letellier through the City of Winnipeg except for Ste. Agathe and St. Jean Baptiste
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Being Issued For The Lakes Within Whiteshell Provincial Park
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning for the lakes within the Whiteshell Provincial Park area. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as levels and flows are rising. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing water or waters of unknown depth. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-05T15:00:00-06:00

Area: Whiteshell Provincial Park

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. The snow squalls are forecast to begin early this morning and persist through this afternoon. The most intense bands are expected later this morning on Highway 11 between Lake Helen and Jellicoe. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T02:31:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T10:32:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0549879769.2019
Area: Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm over the Maritimes late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect New Brunswick into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation, there is a good possibility of accumulating snow, heavy rain and strong winds. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A fast moving low pressure system will make its way through west-central Alberta tonight, bringing significant snowfall amounts to the Rocky Mountain foothills. Total snowfall accumulations will range 10-25 cm in some locations. Higher amounts are possible over higher terrain. For areas further to the south, snow will begin overnight into Tuesday morning and persist throughout the day. Snowfall warnings may be expanded overnight to include regions west of Calgary. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-05T19:08:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T03:09:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0616526762.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm affecting the Islands late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect the Iles-de-la-Madeleine into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation, there is a possibility of accumulating snow, rainfall and strong winds. The storm will cause higher than normal water levels as well as large waves and rough and pounding surf, mainly along coastlines where winds blow onshore. It is too early to give specifics on impacts and areas to be affected. Additional information will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T00:45:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T08:46:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2812367337.2019
Area: ÃŽles-de-la-Madeleine

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential storm over the Maritimes late in the week. A storm will likely develop Friday and affect Nova Scotia into the weekend. While it is too soon to provide specific details on precipitation types and amounts, there is a possibility of accumulating snow, heavy rainfall and strong winds. At this time, accumulating snow is looking less likely for Nova Scotia, especially for southern areas. Large waves may impact coastlines where strong winds blow onshore. This is most likely to occur over western Cape Breton where strong westerly winds blow onshore Friday night and Saturday. It is too early to give specifics on impacts and areas to be affected. Additional information will be provided it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-06T00:39:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-05T08:40:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2361052961.2019

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Island Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for the Cowichan Valley because of high concentrations of fine particulates that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Open burning restrictions are now in effect for the Cowichan Valley within 20 kilometres of Duncan City Hall for a period of 2 days. No new fires may be initiated and no additional material may be added to existing fires. For more information on burning restrictions, see the section entitled â€˜Mandatory Emission Reduction Actionsâ€™ and for more information on current air quality, see: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### Exposure to air pollution is particularly a concern for children, the elderly, and those who have underlying medical conditions such as lung or heart disease. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-11-06T01:08:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-11-05T09:41:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2544611187.2019
Area: Duncan
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment
